tn.text: This continues the missionary journeys of Paul with Silas.
Timothy is introduced into the story and joins Paul and Silas. Verses 1 and 2 give background information about Timothy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
The first, third, and fourth instances of the word "him" refer to Timothy. The second "him" refers to Paul.
Here "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
This is the name of a city in Asia Minor. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:act:14:05|14:6]].
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the narrative. Your language may have a way of doing this.
The words "in Christ" are understood. AT: "who believed in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: He was well spoken of by the brothers
tn.text: This can be stated in active from. AT: "The brothers spoke well of him" or "Timothy had a good reputation among the brothers" or "The brothers said good things about him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "brothers" refers to believers. AT: "by the believers"
It is possible that Paul himself circumcised Timothy, but it is more likely that he had someone else circumcise Timothy.

tn.ref: because of the Jews that were in those parts
tn.text: "because of the Jews living in the areas where Paul and Timothy would be traveling"

tn.ref: for they all knew that his father was a Greek
tn.text: Since Greek men did not have their sons circumcised, the Jews would have known Timothy was not circumcised, and they would have rejected Paul and Timothy before hearing their message about Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "they" here refers to Paul, Silas ([[:en:bible:notes:act:15:39|15:40]]), and Timothy ([[:en:bible:notes:act:16:01|16:3]]).
"they told to the believers in the churches there"
"for the church members to obey" or "for the believers to obey"

tn.ref: that had been written by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that the apostles and elders in Jerusalem had written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the churches were strengthened in the faith and increased in number daily
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The believers became stronger in their faith, and there were more and more people becoming believers every day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the churches were strengthened in the faith
tn.text: This speaks of helping someone to believe more confidently as if it were making them physically stronger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here this stands for the believers in the churches. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a region in Asia. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:08|2:10]].

tn.ref: they had been forbidden by the Holy Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Holy Spirit had forbidden them" or "the Holy Spirit did not permit them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
Here "word" stands for "message." AT: "the message about Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "came" can be translated as "went" or "arrived." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
These are two more regions in Asia. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"the Holy Spirit"

tn.ref: they came down to the city of Troas
tn.text: The phrase "came down" is used here because Troas is lower in elevation than Mysia.
Here "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Here the word "him" refers to Paul.
The word "we" is inclusive and refers to Paul and his companions including Luke, the author of Acts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

The first use of "us" refers to the people in Macedonia. The second use of "us" refers to Paul and his companions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
The word "them" refers to the people of Macedonia.
"Paul saw a vision from God" or "Paul had a vision from God"
"begging him" or "inviting him"
The phrase "Come over" is used because Macedonia is across the sea from Troas.
Paul and his companions are now in Philippi on their missionary trip. Verse 13 begins the story of Lydia. This short story happens during Paul's travels.
The word "we" is inclusive and refers to Paul and his companions including Luke, the author of Acts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive|Inclusive "We"]])
These are coastal cities near Phillipi in Macedonia. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here "came to" can be translated as "went to" or "arrived at." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

This is a city outside of Italy where many people who came from Rome lived. It had the same rights and freedoms as a city in Italy. They could govern themselves and they did not have to pay taxes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This ends the story of Lydia.
Here "A certain woman" introduces a new person in the story. AT: "There was a woman named Lydia" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Here "cloth" is understood. AT: "a merchant who sold purple cloth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
A worshiper of God is a Gentile who gives praise to God and follows him, but does not obey all of the Jewish laws.

tn.ref: The Lord opened her heart to pay attention to the things
tn.text: For the Lord to cause someone to pay attention and to be receptive to Paul's message is spoken of as if he were opening a person's heart. AT: "The Lord caused her to understand and pay close attention to the things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "heart" stands for a person's mind. Also, the author speaks about the "heart" or "mind" as if it were a box that a person could open so it is ready for someone to fill it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the things which were spoken by Paul
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the things which Paul spoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: When she was baptized, and her household
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "When they baptized Lydia and members of her household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This begins the first event in another short story during Paul's travels; it is about a young fortune teller.

Background information is given here to explain that this young fortune teller brought much financial gain to her masters by guessing people's futures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This phrase marks the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
The phrase "a certain" introduces a new person to the story. AT: "there was a young woman" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
An evil spirit spoke to her often about the immediate future of people.
How a person can be saved is spoken of here as if it were a way or path that a person walks on. AT: "how God can save you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: But Paul, being greatly annoyed by her, turned
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But she greatly annoyed Paul so he turned around" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in the name of Jesus Christ
tn.text: Here "name" stands for speaking with the authority or as the representative of Jesus Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: And it came out right away
tn.text: "And the spirit came out immediately"
Here the word "them" refers to Paul and Silas but not Timothy and Luke.
Here the first two uses of the word "they" refer to the masters of the girl who had been fortunetelling. The third use of the word "they" refers to Paul and Silas.
Here the masters' use of the word "us" includes the authorities in their claim since they were also Romans. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive|Inclusive "We"]])
"the owners of the slave girl"
This refers to the ability the girl had of divination or telling the future and for people to pay for her prophecies.
"into the public square." This is a public place of business, where buying and selling of goods, cattle, or services takes place.
"into the presence of the authorities" or "so that the authorities could judge them"

tn.ref: When they had brought them to the magistrates
tn.text: "When they had brought them to the judges"
"rulers" or "judges"
"to believe or to obey" or "to accept or to do"
Here the words "their" and "them" refer to Paul and Silas.
The word "they" here refers to soldiers.

tn.ref: commanded them to be beaten with rods
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "commanded the soldiers to beat them  with rods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: had laid many blows upon them
tn.text: " had hit them many times with rods"

tn.ref: commanded the jailer to keep them securely
tn.text: "told the jailer to make sure they did not get out" (UDB)
a person responsible for all the people held in the jail or prison
"he heard this command"

tn.ref: fastened their feet in the stocks
tn.text: "securely locked their feet in the stocks"
a piece of wood with holes for preventing a person's feet from moving
This continues Paul and Silas' time in Philippi in prison and tells what happens to their jailer.
The word "them" refers to Paul and Silas.

tn.ref: earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "earthquake which shook the foundations of the prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
When the foundations shook, this caused the entire prison to shake. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "all the doors opened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "everyone's chains came loose" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "we" refers to Paul, Silas, and all of the other prisoners but excludes the jailer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: The jailer was awakened from sleep
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The jailer woke up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"was ready to kill himself." The jailer preferred to commit suicide rather than suffer the consequences of letting the prisoners escape.
The reason why the jailer needed light can be made explicit. AT: "called for someone to bring light so he could see who was still in the prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "lights" stands for something that makes light. AT: "for torches" or "for lamps" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"quickly entered the jail"

tn.ref: fell down before Paul and Silas
tn.text: The jailer humbled himself by bowing down at the feet of Paul and Silas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"led them outside the jail"

tn.ref: what must I do to be saved
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "what must I do for God to save me from my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will save you" or "God will save you from your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "house" stands for the people who live in the house. AT: "all the members of your household" or "your family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the first use of the word "they" as well as the words "their" and "them" refer to Paul and Silas. Compare [[:en:bible:notes:act:16:25|16:25]]. The last use of the word "they" refers to the people in the jailers' household.
The words "him," "his," and "he" refer to the jailer.

tn.ref: They spoke the word of the Lord to him
tn.text: Here "word" stands for a message. AT: "They told him the message about the Lord Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he and all his household were baptized
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Paul and Silas baptized the jailer and all members of his household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This is the last event in the story of Paul and Silas in Philippi. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:16:11|16:12]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke tells the last event in the story that started in [[:en:bible:notes:act:16:16|16:16]].
Here "word" stands for "message" or "command." AT: "sent a message to the guards" or "sent a command to the guards" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sent" means the magistrates told someone to go tell the guards their message.
"Release those men" or "Allow those men to leave"
"come outside of the jail"

All of the times the word "they" is used and the first time "them" is used, the words refer to the magistrates. The word "themselves" refers to the magistrates. The second time the word "them" is used, it refers to Paul and Silas.
The word "us" refers only to Paul and Silas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
Probably Paul is speaking to the jailer, but he intends for the jailer to tell the magistrates what he says. AT: "said to the jailer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "They" refers to the magistrates who commanded their soldiers to beat them. AT: "The magistrates ordered their soldiers to beat us in public" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: men who are uncondemned Romans, and have thrown us into prison
tn.text: "men who are Roman citizens, and they had their soldiers put us in jail though they had not proven in court that we were guilty"

tn.ref: and do they now drive us out secretly? No indeed
tn.text: Paul uses a question to emphasize that he will not allow the magistrates to send them out the city in secret after they had  mistreated Paul and Silas. AT: "I will certainly not let them send us out of the city in secret!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "themselves" is used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: the magistrates were afraid when they heard that Paul and Silas were Romans
tn.text: To be a Roman meant to be a legal citizens of the Empire. Citizenship provided freedom from torture and the right to a fair trial. The city leaders were afraid that more important Roman authorities might learn how the city leaders had mistreated Paul and Silas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])
This is the end of Paul and Silas' time in Philippi. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
Here the word "they" refers to Paul and Silas. The word "them" refers to the believers in Philippi.
Here "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"the home of Lydia"
Here "brothers" refers to believers whether male or female. AT: "saw the believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
